content:
Check:
  all:
    - name: TSVALNF
      operator: empty
    - name: TSVAL
      operator: prefix_matches_regex
      value: (NI|OTH|NINF|PINF|UNK|ASKU|NAV|NASK|TRC|MSK|NA|QS)
Core:
  Id: CDISC.SDTMIG.CG0291
  Version: '1'
  Status: Draft
Description: When TSVALNF is null, TSVAL should not be populated with an ISO 21090
  term or other null flavor.  This rule has been executed with the understanding that
  non-ISO 21090 terms may not be flagged, and there may be exceptions where the term
  has been used appropriately.
Outcome:
  Message: TSVAL is populated with an ISO 21090 or null flavor term
Rule Type: Record Data
Sensitivity: Record
Authorities:
  - Organization: CDISC
    Standards:
      - Name: SDTMIG
        Version: '3.4'
        References:
          - Origin: SDTM and SDTMIG Conformance Rules
            Rule Identifier:
              Id: CG0291
              Version: '1'
            Version: '2.0'
            Citations:
              - Cited Guidance: 'While it would be possible to allow a value such
                  as NONE or UNBOUNDED to be entered in TSVAL, validation programs
                  would then have to recognize this special term as an exception to
                  the expected data format. Therefore, it was decided that a separate
                  null flavor variable that uses the ISO 21090 null flavor terminology
                  would be a better solution. '
                Document: IG v3.4
                Section: 7.4.2.1
Scope:
  Classes:
    Include:
      - TRIAL DESIGN
  Domains:
    Include:
      - TS

json.Description: When TSVALNF is null, TSVAL should not be populated with an ISO 21090 term or other null flavor.  This rule has been executed with the understanding that non-ISO 21090 terms may not be flagged, and there may be exceptions where the term has been used appropriately.

Outcome.Message: TSVAL is populated with an ISO 21090 or null flavor term

Citations.Cited_Guidance: While it would be possible to allow a value such as NONE or UNBOUNDED to be entered in TSVAL, validation programs would then have to recognize this special term as an exception to the expected data format. Therefore, it was decided that a separate null flavor variable that uses the ISO 21090 null flavor terminology would be a better solution.
